tn.text: In order to warn his fellow believers about Jews who would try to get them to follow the old laws, Paul gives his own testimony about when he persecuted believers.
"Now moving along, my brothers" or "Concerning other matters, my brothers"
Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:php:01:12|1:12]].
"be happy because of all the Lord has done"
annoying

tn.ref: These things will keep you safe
tn.text: Here "these things" refers to Paul's teachings. You can add this alternate translation to the end of the previous sentence. AT: "because these teachings will protect you from those who teach what is not true" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"Beware of" or "Look out for"

tn.ref: the dogs ... the evil workers ... the mutilation
tn.text: These are three different ways of describing the same group of false teachers. Paul is using strong expressions to convey his feeling about these Jewish Christian teachers.

The word "dogs" was used by the Jews to refer to those who were not Jews. They were considered unclean. Paul speaks of the false teachers as though they were dogs, to insult them. If you have a different animal in your culture that is considered unclean or whose name is used as an insult, you could use this animal instead. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])

Paul is exaggerating about the act of circumcision to insult the false teachers. The false teachers said God will only save a person who is circumcised, who cuts off the foreskin. This action was required by the law of Moses for all male Israelites. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]] and  [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Paul uses "we" to refer to himself and all true believers in Christ, including the Philippian believers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

Paul uses this phrase to refer to believers in Christ who are not physically circumcised but are spiritually circumcised, which means they have received the Holy Spirit through faith. "truly God's people"

tn.ref: have no confidence in the flesh
tn.text: "do not trust that only cutting our flesh will please God"
"Yet" or "However"

tn.ref: I myself could have confidence in the flesh. If anyone thinks he has confidence in the flesh, I could have even more
tn.text: This is a hypothetical situation that Paul does not believe is possible. Paul says if it were possible that God would save people based on what they did, then God would certainly have saved him. AT: "No one can do enough things to please God, but if anyone could do enough things to please God, I could do more good things and please God more than anyone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
Paul uses "myself" for emphasis. "certainly I"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "A priest circumcised me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"seven days after I was born" (UDB)
Possible meanings are 1) "a Hebrew son with Hebrew parents" or 2) "the purest Hebrew."

tn.ref: in respect to the law, a Pharisee
tn.text: The only way a Jew could become a Pharisee was to be born to a Pharisee father. But this put upon the person a duty to live as a Pharisee, with a special devotion to the law of Moses. "as a Pharisee, I was completely devoted to the law"
Paul says here that he had been very eager to punish people for following Christ. "I was very determined to hurt Christian believers"

tn.ref: In respect to the righteousness of the law, I was blameless
tn.text: "I obeyed the law completely"

tn.ref: whatever things were a profit for me
tn.text: Paul is referring here to the praise he received for being an eager Pharisee. He speaks of this praise as if he had viewed it in the past as a businessman's profit. AT: "anything that other Jews praised me for" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I have considered them as loss
tn.text: Paul speaks of that praise as if he were now viewing it as a business loss instead of a profit. In other words, Paul says that all his religious acts of righteousness are worthless before Christ. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"Really" or "Truly"

The word "now" emphasizes how Paul has changed since he quit being a Pharisee and became a believer in Christ. AT: "now that I have trusted in Christ, I count" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: I count all things to be loss
tn.text: Paul is continuing the business metaphor from [[:en:bible:notes:php:03:06|3:7]], saying it is worthless to trust in anything other than Christ. "I consider everything to be worthless" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: because of the excellency of the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord
tn.text: "because knowing Christ Jesus my Lord is worth so much more"

tn.ref: For him I have discarded all things
tn.text: "Because of him I have willingly thrown everything else away"
Use your usual word for putting unwanted things away from you forever.

Paul speaks of the things a person may trust in as if it were waste that is thrown out. He is emphasizing how worthless they really are. AT: "I think of them as trash" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: so that I may gain Christ
tn.text: "so that I may have Christ alone"
The phrase "be found" is an idiom that emphasizes the idea of "to be." AT: "and be truly united with Christ" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: I do not have a righteousness of my own from the law
tn.text: "I am not trying to please God on my own by obeying the law"
"his power that gives us life"
"suffer as he suffered, as though we were suffering the same things in the same place at the same time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I want to be transformed into the likeness of his death
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) Paul wants Christ to change him so that he can die as Christ died or 2) he wants his desire to sin to become as dead as Jesus was before he was raised. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: so somehow I may experience the resurrection from the dead
tn.text: The word "somehow" means Paul does not know what is going to happen to him in this life, but whatever happens, it will result in eternal life. "so that, no matter what happens to me now, I will come back to life after I die"

Paul urges the believers at Philippi to follow his present example because of heaven and the new bodies that wait for believers. He speaks of how he works as hard as he can to be like Christ, knowing that God will allow him to live forever in heaven, as if he were a runner racing for the finish line.
These include knowing Christ, knowing the power of his resurrection, sharing in Christ's suffering, and being united with Christ in his death and resurrection ([[:en:bible:notes:php:03:08|3:8-11]]).

tn.ref: or that I have become complete
tn.text: "so I am not yet perfect" or "so I am not yet mature"
"But I keep trying" (UDB)
"I may receive these things"

tn.ref: that for which I was grasped by Christ Jesus
tn.text: This can be stated in an active form. AT: "because that is why Jesus claimed me as his own" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive|Active or Passive]])
Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:php:01:12|1:12]].

tn.ref: I myself have yet grasped it
tn.text: "all these things belong to me yet"

tn.ref: I forget what is behind and strain for what is ahead
tn.text: Like a runner in a race is no longer concerned about the part of the race that is completed but only focuses on what is ahead, Paul speaks of setting aside his religious works of righteousness and only focusing on the race of life that Christ has set before him to complete. AT: "I do not care what I have done in the past; I only work as hard as I can on what is ahead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor|Metaphor]])

tn.ref: I press on toward the goal to win the prize of the upward calling of God in Christ Jesus
tn.text: As a runner presses onward to win the race, Paul presses onward in serving and living in obedience to Christ. AT: "I do all I can to be like Christ, like a runner racing to the finish line, so that I may belong to him, and God may call me to himself after I die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor|Metaphor]])

Possible meanings are that Paul speaks of living eternally with God as if God were to call Paul to ascend 1) to heaven as Jesus did or 2) the steps to the podium where winners of races received prizes, as a metaphor for meeting God face to face and receiving eternal life. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor|Metaphor]])

tn.ref: All of us who are mature, let us think this way
tn.text: Paul wants his fellow believers to have the same desires he listed in [[:en:bible:notes:php:03:08|3:8-11]]. AT: "I encourage all of us believers who are strong in the faith to think the same way"

tn.ref: God will also reveal that to you
tn.text: "God will also make it clear to you" or "God will make sure you know it"

tn.ref: whatever we have reached, let us hold on to it
tn.text: "let us all continue obeying the same truth we have already received" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
"Do what I do" or "Live as I live"
Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:php:01:12|1:12]].

tn.ref: those who are walking by the example that you have in us
tn.text: "those who already are living as I live" or "those who already are doing what I do"

tn.ref: Many are walking ... as enemies of the cross of Christ
tn.text: These words are Paul's main thought for this verse.
"Many are living" or "Many are conducting their lives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: those about whom I have often told you, and now I am telling you with tears
tn.text: Paul interrupts his main thought with these words that describe the "many." You can move them to the beginning or end of the verse if you need to.
"I have told you many times"
"am telling you with great sadness"

tn.ref: as enemies of the cross of Christ
tn.text: Here "the cross of Christ" refers to Christ's suffering and death. The enemies are those who say they believe in Jesus but are not willing to suffer or die like Jesus did. AT: "in a way that shows they are actually against Jesus, who was willing to suffer and die on a cross" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Someday God will destroy them"

Here "stomach" refers to a person's desires for physical pleasure. Calling it their god means that they want these pleasures more than they want to obey God. AT: "they desire food and other physical pleasures more than they desire to obey God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: their pride is in their shame
tn.text: Here "shame" stands for the actions that the people should be ashamed about but are not. AT: "they are proud of the things that should cause them shame" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here "earthly" refers to everything that gives physical pleasure and does not honor God. AT: "All they think about is what will please themselves rather than what will please God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
By Paul's use of "our" and "we" here, he includes himself and the believers in Philippi. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
Possible meanings are 1) "we are citizens of heaven" (UDB) or 2) "our homeland is heaven" or 3) "our true home is heaven."

tn.ref: He will transform our lowly bodies
tn.text: "He will change our weak, earthly bodies"

tn.ref: into bodies formed like his glorious body
tn.text: "into bodies like his glorious body"

tn.ref: body, formed by the might of his power to subject all things to himself
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "body. He will change our bodies with the same power he uses to control all things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
